For a meromorphic function $f$ let $n(r,a)$ count the number of roots of $f(z)=a$ in the disc $\lvert z\rvert <r$. Does there exist a meromorphic (or entire) $f$ such that for every $a\neq b$\[\limsup_{r\to \infty}\frac{n(r,a)}{n(r,b)}=\infty?\]



This is Problem 1.25 in \cite{Ha74}, where it is attributed to Erd\H{o}s.

Gol'dberg \cite{Go78} and Toppila \cite{To76} have constructed entire functions with this property.




References


[Go78] Gol\cprime dberg, A. A., Counting functions of sequences of {$a$}-points for entire
functions. Sibirsk. Mat. \v Z. (1978), 28--36, 236.

[Ha74] Hayman, W. K., Research problems in function theory: new problems. (1974), 155--180.

[To76] Toppila, Sakari, On the counting function for the {$a$}-values of a meromorphic
function. Ann. Acad. Sci. Fenn. Ser. A I Math. (1976), 565--572.
